awd_titl_txt: Building Community and Capacity for an Internet-Accessible and State-Level Microsimulation Model of Tax and Benefit Policies
awd_abstract_narration:
Social and economic policy increasing involves changes in both benefit programs and the tax systems, yet methods to assess program impacts and interactions are limited, and the available approaches provide primarily federal-level information. This project will develop a complete substantive and technical plan for a new tool for assessing government policies-an Internet-accessible microsimulation model of tax and benefit policies able to estimate the impacts of policy changes at the state level.  A microsimulation model is a complex computer program that mimics the operations of government programs using either actual program rules or hypothetical rules.  Changes in federal tax and benefit policies are often assessed using microsimulation models developed by or for federal government agencies; this project will lay the groundwork for a tool that will allow microsimulation analysis at the state level, and that will be accessible to anyone with Internet access.  With the envisioned model, state government analysts could estimate the cost or caseload impact of a legislatively-proposed change in a tax or benefit program, an academic researcher could assess the impact of a package of changes on state poverty, students could conduct analyses to better understand how programs operate, non-profit policy organizations with competing philosophies could discuss a state policy proposal using quantitative estimates from the same source, and an individual could see how changing programs would affect different families.

The design for the new model will be based on an existing simulation model-the TRIM3 microsimulation model, which is funded and copyrighted by the Department of Health and Human Services, Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation (HHS/ASPE) and developed and maintained by the Urban Institute.  The data source will be the American Community Survey, conducted by the Bureau of the Census, which provides large samples for state-level analysis.  TRIM3 already includes detailed state-level simulations, but it primarily uses a different data source, and its computer architecture and user interface do not allow extensive public access.  The planning for the new model will include three inter-related activities.  First, the researchers will hold meetings and webinars with prospective users, including state government staff, academics, and other individuals interested in state-level policies.  Participants will be asked what modeling capabilities are most important, the type of user interface that is needed, and the types of modeling results that would be most helpful.  Second, the research team will develop prototype designs for the user interface and for results in various formats.  These designs will be shared with the potential community to obtain their reactions and suggested improvements.  Finally, the research team will determine what computer architecture will best support this type of model, allowing multiple users to simultaneously set up and run simulations, with very fast run speeds.  The final written product will be a complete plan for the implementation of the new model.  The work will also result in the development of a community of researchers and policymakers who have applied or who want to apply microsimulation techniques to the analysis of policy options in their states.

por.por_cntn:
Building Community and Capacity for a Web-Accessible and State-Level Microsimulation Model of Tax and Benefit Policies

Final Report submitted to the National Science Foundation, Award SMA-1439656

This project examined the feasibility of a new type of microsimulation model, and the degree to which the model would be used by the intended community. The new model would allow individuals in state government policy offices, universities, and non-profit organizations, as well as private individuals, to go to a website, describe a policy option, and see the estimated impacts of that policy in their state. Specifically, the new model would meet the following criteria:

  • Comprehensive:  able to model policies across a broad range of safety-net programs (Table 1), as well as picking up the interactions across programs
  • State-focused: capable of simulating detailed state-level program rules as well as national rules using input data that enable detailed analysis at the state level
  • Internet-accessible:  able to be accessed by any user with an Internet connection and capable of operating well with many simultaneous users
  • User-friendly interface: able to be used easily by individuals who understand the programs, but who are not experts in simulation modeling
  •  “Baseline” simulations aligned to actual state-level program data:  The model’s representation of current benefits and taxes—who receives and pays, and how much—must come acceptably close to real-world figures, in total, across states, and for demographic subgroups within states.
  • Strong capabilities for modeling alternative policies:  The model should be able to provide answers to a broad range of “what if” questions and enable the modeling of hypothetical changes in program eligibility, program benefits, tax computations, and program interactions.
  • Accessible and intuitive output:  The model should provide a range of output, including extensive graphics geared to less-technical users

Under the auspices of this project we have consulted with a broad range of potential users, in individual conversations and in a group meeting. There has been almost universal enthusiasm on the part of potential users for a comprehensive model they can access themselves; the potential users have also provided important feedback on the most important capabilities of a new model. This project has also included an in-depth exploration of the technical requirements of a new model. Based on that analysis, we are confident that advances in computer technology mean we would be able to build the next generation of complex microsimulation modeling -- harnessing new computer technology to allow a broad community of researchers full access to complex, state-level microsimulation modelling of the benefit and tax policies affecting U.S. households.

With the information gathered from this project we estimate that building and maintaining this model over 5 years would cost approximately $6 million. We believe that many different individuals would greatly welcome the kind of model that we would like to build—a web-based public microsimulation model to calculate the effects of federal and state tax and transfer programs at the state level. Also, we have determined that the model is technically feasible; that is, something could be built that could be accessible to many individuals simultaneously, with a high level of reliability and security. Finally, we have identified tools that would allow us to create a user interface providing different experiences to users wanting different levels of detail.

We will pursue multiple avenues to attempt to obtain funding in order to turn these ideas into an accessible tool for researchers, policymakers, students, and anyone interested in better understanding how government programs affect U.S. families.

 

Table 1

 List of Possible Programs to Include In the Tool  (Mentioned in the Survey Document or Raised by Interviewees)

  • State income tax – very important –
    • Tax credits (child/dependent expense, renters)
    • EITC
    • Self-employment deductions
    • Income and payroll taxes
    • Higher education credits
    • Unemployment, SSI
    • State-level housing assistance programs – but less interested overall
    • GA, SNAP, TANF
      • SNAP more about interactions with other programs than changing specific parameters
      • Child nutrition programs, CCDF
        • Less sure how child support enforcement might work in, but interested
        • ACA  - premium credits
        • Cost-sharing formulas/rules
        • Higher education grants

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: Kim Rueben
